content:
"Complete understanding" refers to a state of having a full and accurate comprehension of all aspects and nuances of something, such that there are no further questions or uncertainties. In practice, complete understanding of complex or abstract concepts can be difficult or impossible to achieve.

"Incomplete but practical understanding," on the other hand, refers to a state of having a partial comprehension of something that is still useful and applicable in a particular context or situation. This type of understanding may be limited by one's background, experiences, or cognitive abilities, and may be subject to revision as new information or perspectives become available.

While complete understanding may be desirable in some contexts, such as scientific inquiry or philosophical analysis, practical understanding can still be valuable and relevant in many everyday situations. For example, you may have an incomplete but practical understanding of how to use a new software program, or an incomplete but practical understanding of another person's perspective on a social issue. In such cases, practical understanding can facilitate communication, collaboration, and problem-solving, even if it is not a complete or perfect understanding.
